item.title: Linear maps
item.description: Also called linear transformations. Definition A linear map from a vector space \(V\) to a vector space \(W\) is a function \(T: V \to W\) with the following properties: additivity: \(T(u + v) = T(u) + T(v)\) for all \(u,v \in V\); homogeneity: \(T(av) = aT(v)\) for all \(v \in V\) and \(a \in \F\). We denote the set of all linear maps from \(V\) to \(W\) by \(\L (V, W)\).

item.title: Matrices
item.description: Definition A matrix is a rectangular array with \(m\) rows and \(n\) columns for positive integers \(m\) and \(n\). \[\begin{bmatrix} a_{1,1} & \dots & a_{1,n} \\ \vdots & \ddots & \vdots \\ a_{m,1} & \dots & a_{m,n} \end{bmatrix}\] A generic matrix looks like the above, where \(a_{i,j}\) are usually elements of \(\F\), either the reals or the complex numbers. Matrix of a linear map If \(V\) and \(W\) are finite-dimensional vector spaces and \(T \in \L(V, W)\) is a linear map, then \(V\) has a basis \((v_1, \dots, v_n)\) and \(W\) has a basis \((w_1, \dots w_m)\).

item.title: Null spaces
item.description:
Also known as kernels… Definition Let \(T \in \L(V,W)\) be a linear map between vector spaces \(V\) and \(W\). The null space of \(T\), denoted \(
ull T\), is the subset of \(V\) containing vectors that \(T\) maps to the zero vector in \(W\), that is, \[
ull T = \{v \in V \mid Tv = 0\}.\] Properties (3.1) Proposition: If \(T \in \L(V,W)\), then \(
ull T\) is a subspace of \(V\).

item.title: Range
item.description: Also known as the image… Definition Let \(T \in \L(V,W)\) be a linear map between vector spaces \(V\) and \(W\). The range of \(T\), denoted \(\range T\), is the subset of \(W\) containing vectors of the form \(Tv\) for some \(v \in V\), that is, \[\range T = \{Tv \mid v \in V\}.\] Properties (3.3) Proposition: If \(T \in \L(V,W)\), then \(\range T\) is a subspace of \(W\). (3.4) Theorem: If \(V\) is a finite-dimensional vector space and \(T \in \L(V,W)\) is a linear map, then \[\dim V = \dim \, \null T + \dim \, \range T,\] where \(\null T\) denotes the null space of \(T\) and \(\dim V\) is the dimension of the space \(V\).

item.title: Vector spaces
item.description: Definitions A vector space over a field \(\F\) (here either \(\R\) or \(\C\)) is a set \(V\), together with addition (\(+\)) and scalar multiplication (\(\cdot\)) operations such that the following properties hold: commutativity: \(u + v = v + u\) for all \(u, v \in V\); associativity: \((u + v) + w = u + (v + w)\) and \((ab)v = a(bv)\) for all \(u,v,w \in V\), \(a,b \in \F\); additive identity: there exists an element \(0 \in V\) such that \(v + 0 = v\) for all \(v \in V\); additive inverse: for every \(v \in V\), there exists an element \(w \in V\) such that \(v + w = 0\); multiplicative identity: \(1v = v\) for all \(v \in V\); distributive properties: \(a(u + v) = au + av\) and \((a + b)v = av + bv\) for all \(v,w \in V\) and \(a,b \in \F\).

item.title: Dimension of a vector space
item.description: Definition The dimension of a finite dimensional vector space \(V\), denoted \(\dim V\), is the length of any basis of \(V\). Properties (2.18) Theorem: If \(U_1\) and \(U_2\) are subspaces of a vector space \(V\), then their sum satisfies \[\dim (U_1 + U_2) = \dim U_1 + \dim U_2 - \dim (U_1 \cap U_2).\] (3.4) Theorem: If \(V\) is a finite-dimensional vector space and \(T \in \L(V,W)\) is a linear map, then \[\dim V = \dim \, \null T + \dim \, \range T,\] where \(\null T\) and \(\range T\) denote the null space and range of \(T\), respectively.

item.title: Products of linear maps
item.description: Definition Let \(U\), \(V\), and \(W\) be vector spaces. If \(T \in \L(U, V)\) and \(S \in \L(V, W)\) are linear maps such that \(T\) maps \(U\) into the domain of \(S\), then we define the product \(ST \in \L(U, W)\) by \((ST)v = S(Tv)\), that is, \(ST\) is the composition \(S \circ T\) of the two maps. Properties Associativity. If \(T_1\), \(T_2\), and \(T_3\) are linear maps such that \(T_3\) maps into the domain of \(T_2\) which in turn maps into the domain of \(T_1\), then \((T_1 T_2) T_3 = T_1 (T_2 T_3)\).

item.title: Basis of a vector space
item.description: Definition Let \(V\) be a vector space. A basis of \(V\) is a list of vectors in \(V\) that is linearly independent and spans \(V\). Properties (2.8) Proposition: A list \((v_1, \dots, v_n)\) is a basis of \(V\) if and only if every \(v \in V\) can be uniquely expressed as a linear combination of \((v_1, \dots, v_n)\). (2.10) Theorem: Every spanning list \((v_1, \dots, v_n)\) of \(V\) can be reduced to a basis by removing some of the \(v_i\) from the list.

item.title: Direct sums of subspaces
item.description: Definition Let \(U_1, \dots, U_m\) be subspaces of a vector space \(V\) such that the sum \(U_1 + \dots + U_m\) is the whole space \(V\). If each element \(v \in V\) can be written uniquely as a sum \(u_1 + \dots + u_m\) where each \(u_i \in U_i\). In this case, we write \(V = U_1 \oplus \dots \oplus U_m\). Properties (1.8) Proposition: Let \(U_1, \dots, U_n\) are subspaces of a vector space \(V\).

item.title: Linear (in)dependence
item.description: Definitions A list of vectors \((v_1, \dots, v_n)\) in a vector space \(V\) is linearly independent if and only if \(a_1 v_1 + \dots + a_n v_n = 0\) implies that \(a_1 = \dots = a_n = 0\). The list is linearly dependent if and only if it is not linearly independent. Note: These definitions follow Sheldon Axler’s book Linear Algebra Done Right, in which linear (in)dependence is defined in terms of lists of vectors, and not sets of vectors.

item.title: Subspaces of a vector space
item.description: Definition Let \(V\) be a vector space. A subset \(U\) of \(V\) is a subspace of \(V\) if and only if it is also a vector space. Properties Since many properties of the vector space \(V\) are inherited, a subset \(U\) is a subspace provided it satisfies the following: additive identity: \(0 \in U\); closed under addition: \(u,v \in U\) implies \(u + v \in U\); closed under scalar multiplication: \(a \in \F\), \(v \in V\) implies \(av \in U\).

item.title: Sums of subspaces
item.description: Definition Let \(U_1, \dots, U_m\) be subspaces of a vector space \(V\). The sum of \(U_1, \dots, U_m\) is \[U_1 + \dots + U_m = \{u_1 + \dots + u_m \mid u_1 \in U_1, \dots, u_m \in U_m\},\] the set of all possible sums of elements of the \(U_i\). Properties The sum of subspaces \(U_1 + \dots + U_m\) is a subspace. \(0 \in U_i\) for all \(i = 1, \dots, m\), so \(0 = \overbrace{0 + \dots + 0}^{m \text{ times}} \in U_1 + \dots + U_m\).

item.title: Linear combinations
item.description: Definition Let \(V\) be a vector space over \(\F\) and let \((v_1, \dots, v_n)\) be a list of vectors in \(V\). A linear combination of this list is a vector of the form \[a_1 v_1 + \dots + a_n v_n\] where \(a_1, \dots, a_n \in \F\). Examples The vector \((7,2,9) \in \R^3\) is a linear combination of the vectors \((2,1,3)\) and \((1,0,1)\) since \[(7,2,9) = 2(2,1,3) + 3(1,0,1)\]

item.title: Span
item.description: Definition Let \(v_1, \dots, v_n \in V\) be vectors in a vector space over \(\F\). The span of the list \((v_1, \dots, v_n)\), denoted \(\Span(v_1, \dots, v_n)\), is the set of all linear combinations, that is \[\Span(v_1, \dots, v_n) = \{a_1 v_1 + \dots + a_n v_n \mid a_1, \dots, a_n \in \F \}.\] Properties For a list of vectors \((v_1, \dots, v_n)\) in \(V\), \(\Span(v_1, \dots, v_n)\) is a subspace of \(V\).
